tl.def: we don’t have a choice; I give up; c’est la vie; shit happens; it's inevitable; it can't be helped; we can’t help it; we can’t do anything about it; that’s life; we did what we could; it’s out of our hands; it is what it is; oh well; the situation’s hopeless; there’s nothing we can do; we did the best we could; what more can anyone do; it’s no use; not our choice; too bad; there’s just no reasoning with you; whatever; if you must; sheesh, okay; we just have to do it; there's no point fighting it; we're out of luck; that's what I get; what's done is done; them's the breaks; what do you expect?; you've forced my hand; fine, then; hardly my fault!; sometimes it just be like that; rip
tl.defexp: General list for the good 'ol term for those unpleasant situations that can't be helped.

tl.def: no way around it; gotta bite the bullet; we have no choice; we're out of options; guess I gotta; it is what it is; such is life; them's the breaks; ugh, fine!
good and evil; face and heel; heroes and villains; light and dark; reputable and shady; law and chaos; public and underworld
tl.defexp: A fairly common shorthand referring to two sides that exist in a dichotomy, whether it's due to moral alignment or position in society.

lit: I won't let you do that

tl.def: not on my watch; oh no you won't
tl.defexp: Often said right before a character tries to stop someone else. Used on its own, what is させない-ed here is contextual.

A metaverse refers to a virtual reality, implying that the physical and virtual world are linked. A smart take given how characters access the "isekai" through a phone app that transports them to another version of their world. It also allows for terms such as MetaNav (o. イセカイナビ)
Refers to ガッツ when used by itself in a dialogue.
ala "step on the throttle"

"This word does NOT strictly refer to fruit juice; in colloquial speech it actually means 'soda'
Yes, that means you could call any kind of carbonated drink ジュース, regardless of how much (if any) fruit juice it contains"

"This word has 2 additional meanings in the context of fiction and stories: 'lore' and 'setting'.
You could say that Dark Souls has rich 世界観, or that Arknights has a bleak 世界観"
Refers to how one approaches and does things in a certain discipline; their "view" of it, if you will.
Used in marketing

"This word comes up A LOT in a project I worked on recently, and it's not until after I was done translating it that I realized how horribly I'd messed up
You see, this word is often used to refer to what we'd call 'dungeons,' like you'd see in the Zelda series"

"Whenever I see an inappropriate direct translation of this word, it's like hearing nails on a chalkboard.
It's VERY OFTEN used as an endearing term for something the speaker adores, such as a pet or a favorite vehicle or weapon."

"This one is admittedly quite specific It's basically internet slang for a bunch of words that start with 突, e.g. 突撃 and 突然.
In the context of mobile games it's usually a shorthand for (限界)突破 ('limit break') and maxed-out characters/equipment/skills."

tl.def: having nothing better to do; bored
tl.defexp: "This word has a handful of meanings, but the one the dictionary won't tell you about is 'having nothing better to do,' or simply 'bored'"
tl.jpsam: ま、暇だし; 暇だね～
tl.ensam: Got nothing better to do anyway; Someone's bored, huh.

tl.defexp:
"You might assume お茶 is the more broad word for tea, but it's actually the opposite
お茶 by default refers to green tea, while 紅茶 is more in line with what we in the west would refer to as 'tea' in the general sense."

"You might assume お茶 is the more broad word for tea, but it's actually the opposite
お茶 by default refers to green tea, while 紅茶 is more in line with what we in the west would refer to as 'tea' in the general sense."
Blanket term for sword in Japanese, not to be confused with just katanas. The Japanese equivalent is 日本刀.
Blanket term for alcohol in Japanese, not to be confused with just sake. The Japanese equivalent is 日本酒.

"While 'pride' isn't necessarily a mistranslation, it's important to note that the word carries different connotations in Japanese. Often, its nuance is closer to 'self-esteem' or 'dignity' rather than 'hubris.'"

tl.def: to lure; to seduce; to tempt
tl.defexp: "I dunno if this is on other people's radars as much as mine (I translate romance) but most people are so used to this word meaning 'to invite' that they don't know it also means 'to lure, to seduce, to tempt.' I've seen this mistake in game translations multiple times."
tl.jpsam: 誘ってるの?
tl.ensam: Are you hitting on me?

tl.def: the widely accepted way of understanding / doing something
(a usual or common) strategy; play; move; by the book / playing it safe method
tl.jpsam: ここはセオリーどおりに、バントするのが順当だろう。
tl.ensam: The usual thing to do in this situation is bunt.

tl.defexp: "Like in 正義の味方"

tl.def: dissatisfaction with your first try and wanting to attempt it again
try again; be back; have a redo; win; claim victory next time; bounce back / comeback next time; turn the tables / turn the tide next time

tl.defexp: Relates to "Image training" where one visualizes the scenario in their mind to prime themselves for the real thing.

tl.def: to imagine; to visualize; to evoke

tl.defexp: Often refers to a person's quality that's palpable, almost visible, literally or figuratively. As such, a proper translation can be elusive since "aura" is only one of many ways to write it.
Used when describing a person, it doesn't necessarily mean they're slow, more air-headed and frivolous.
Like "Oh boy! It's just one thing after another, huh."

tl.def: bourbon and branch; whisky cut with water; whisky with water
that's all I needed; welcome back; that's more like it; that's the way; now you're speaking my language
tl.defexp: A colloquialism usually said in reaction when things go the way one wants, hopes, or expects.

tl.def: I had nothing to do, so; but what's the alternative?
it hurts; it stings; this sucks; it's regrettable; how disappointing; goddamnit!
tl.defexp: Adjectives like these are conveniently expressed in JP, especially in dialogue, but can be tricky to translate. Find out what emotion the "frustration" stems from and go from there.

tl.def: I hate to admit it, but...; I'm still dealing with it, but...
thank you; thank goodness; how delightful; what a joy; I'm flattered
tl.defexp: Adjectives like these are conveniently expressed in JP, especially in dialogue, but can be tricky to translate. Find out where the "happiness" comes from and go from there.
The idea comes from Romanticism; being able to freely express oneself as an artist. That can be construed as "Romantic" but it's not about romantic love.

Sometimes paired with a verb indicating it going up or down, "Tension" is often not a good way of translating it. For clarity's sake, it's worth going one step deeper and identifying what the emotion is.

tl.def: hype; excitement; thrill; energy; peppiness; raring-to-go
I should be the one saying that, not you!; took the words right out of my mouth; speak for yourself; right back at you; what do you mean X? That would be you!

tl.defexp: Referring to how a team does things or their general gameplan.
Usually refers to a pretty significant difference.
Used in the context of apologizing to someone "properly" instead of on the phone or mail.

tl.def: giving due diligence; thoroughly; dotting t's, crossing i's
respectfully; correctly; with care; get one's act together (as ちゃんとする)

tl.defexp: This term can be quite invisible as there are many ways to translate around it, but this is one way to make it explicit in a sentence.
A bit of a harder take, but "Trauma" in JP also tends to refer to the effects of trauma (ie. neurosis).
"Complex" can be too broad, as there are terms in EN such as "superiority complex" that has its own term in JP.

tl.def: exactly; you got it; uh-huh; indeed; you have a point

tl.defexp: It depends on the character in question, where mad can be too much and upset might be just right.

okay; huh; interesting; that makes sense; uh-huh; oh, cool; wow!; that's great!; really?; is that so?; yikes...; oh...; I'm sorry (to hear that); eureka!; but of course!; aha!; that's it!; I've got it!
condo (US, CA); condominium (US, CA); apartment building (US); block of flats (EN_GB)
tl.defexp: Mansion is technically correct in British English (?) but too obscure of a meaning, so just don't use it even if you use British English.
Sarcasm.
Compared to ドライ.

tl.def: hardcore enthusiast; real fanatic; crazy about...; otaku (works as-is sometimes); geek
tl.jpsam: あいつは根っからの車オタクだよね
tl.ensam: That dude is absolutely crazy about cars.

tl.defexp: Pervert is correct, but not always the most natural-sounding choice

tl.def: strict; tough; serious; disciplined; dedicated; diligent

tl.defexp: When used to describe romantic but non-sexual affection.

tl.def: ropes course; adventure course; obstacle course; parkour

romakana: じゅんちょーじゃない

tl.def: y'all good?; working hard, or hardly working?; how's progress?; everything moving along?; how's it going? -> going good!; how am I doing?; I'm good at this!; will you look at that?!; sometimes I even surprise myself; it’s really coming along; things are coming together; looking good; making good time; doing alright so far

lit:
attack (correct in many contexts, such as music, sports and
video games)

tl.def: try; attempt; assault (mountaineering); make a move (romantic contexts)
tracksuit; sweatsuit; jogging suit; sweats; trackies (UK, AU)

tl.defexp: Software development

lit: futon (can cause confusion with the western couch variety)

tl.def: bed; bedding; mattress; duvet; comforter (US); doona (AU); cushion

romakana: えんがみちびくだろう？

tl.def: the ties that bind you will show you the way
[more than one word]; a few words
tl.defexp: "Because in English, it sounds wonky to describe someone as saying "just one thing" and then having them say multiple words. By moving away from translating 一言 literally, you can still emphasize how brief the statement is while having a sentence that reads much more naturally."
tl.jpsam: 彼が一言を言った
tl.ensam: He said just three words.

tl.def: life is easy for him; got it on easy street
tl.defexp: 余裕がある can be a pain in the ass when it's not about something concrete like money, time.'
Refer to sources for explanation.
"Watch out for 急 when translating. 'A sudden visit' or 'a sudden rain' is really odd English. It's a lot more natural to use 'unexpected.'"
"目を細めて does NOT mean to glare or stare daggers at someone like it would in English, but the opposite - to look at someone fondly. Like a kitty slow blink."

term: ぬぉおおおおおおおおお

tl.def: totally agree lol; that’s true lol
tl.defexp: Used in informal conversations / texts

tl.def: nothing personal; don't take it personally
tl.defexp: Mainly as a one-liner.

tl.def: rinse and repeat; and so on and so on; etc. etc.
tl.defexp: My first exposure to this was through an old internet meme (mid-2000's) so this may not be used as much anymore, but basically it's along the same lines as "ry)" where the speaker assumes the reader is very familiar with the context (or can clearly tell where the topic is going).
tl.jpsam: やる気でない！何もしない！金が無い！でも働くあてがない！だから外出ない！やる気でない！以下省略　これがニート悪循環
tl.ensam: I'm depressed! I do nothing all day! I've got no money, but I don't see the point in working! That's why I never leave my home! Because I'm depressed! Rinse and repeat - this is the vicious cycle of being a NEET!

tl.def: GOAT; goated; greatest of all time; top-tier
tl.defexp: This word is slang that refers to something utterly incredible or the best of its kind. Often used as a prefix, sometimes also as a verb (神る).
tl.jpsam: いやぁこれは神曲だよな
tl.ensam: Maaan this song is so fucking goated

term: 言いたいことだけ言って(...)
romakana: いいたいことだけいって(...)

tl.defexp: Most often used in light/visual novels as narration when a character shows up all of a sudden, monologues, and then leaves.
tl.jpsam: 言いたいことだけ言って、彼女が消えてしまう。
tl.ensam: Now that she's said her piece, she vanishes without lingering a moment longer.

lit: could it be; is it possible; maybe [...]

tl.def: I just had a thought; looking back at it now; what if; you mean to say...
tl.defexp: Frequently used as a way to bring up a point of speculation, whether based on a hunch or actual evidence
tl.jpsam: もしかして…昨日のことも全部放映されていた…？
tl.ensam: What you're saying is... they broadcast EVERYTHING that happened yesterday?

tl.def: hahaha; ha ha ha; he heh heh; tee hee; haw haw; ho ho; giggling
tl.defexp: Don't be afraid to ham it up a bit. It's a more playful (or sleazy) laugh a character might do because they're teasing someone, having some good 'ol ribbing, or planning something behind their back.

romakana: なんとなくかいぜんする

term: 喧嘩売ってんのかい? カカッテコイ!
romakana: けんかうってんのかい？かかってこい!

tl.def: you wanna catch these hands? Because they're on sale today for FREE for you.

lit: getting one's just deserts; reap what you sow

tl.defexp: A complicated term since it originates from a perception that women must be good at housework, beauty, and other feminine stereotypes. In that sense, it can also apply to an individual of any gender who is capable of such things.

tl.def: shut up (overused but to the point); shut your pie hole; keep it down; pipe down; would you please; that's enough; yeah, yeah...
so you're just going to let them get away with it?

romakana: なんだよ, いきなり

tl.def: where's this coming from?; where'd that come from?; that's a bit outta the blue; what brought that on?

tl.defexp: "Used when you make a (cheesy) pun. Usually used in inverted word order and put at the end of a sentence/remark."
tl.jpsam: 今週の金曜日はエビフライ食べない？フライデーだけに
tl.ensam: How about eating deep fried shrimps this Friday? Because it's "Fry-day", you know?

tl.defexp: (, あらら) is coming from another character.

"アラサー is an abbreviation for the English phrase 'around thirty' and describes people around 30 years old (26, 27 ~ 33, 34). Likewise, 'アラフォー' means 'around forty' and 'アラフィフ' means 'around fifty'. アラサー sometimes contains a connotation that they are not young anymore."
tl.jpsam: アラサーになると婚活を始(はじ)める人が多(おお)い
tl.ensam: Many people start 婚活 when they’re around 30.

tl.defexp: A euphemistic definition of the term.
tl.jpsam: その企画を採用していただけないでしょうか / それはむずかしいよ
tl.ensam: Can you adopt this plan? / No, it's not feasible.

tl.defexp: Courtesy of Kenkyusha
tl.jpsam: 彼は無類の堅物だから、そんなところに誘っても行かないよ
tl.ensam: He's such a square he'd never agree to go to a place like that.

term: そんなこと言われても、無理！
romakana: そんなこといわれても,　むり!
lit: even if you tell me that, I can't!

tl.def: save your breath, it's just not gonna happen; listen, four words: no way, no how; you're asking me for the impossible, you know that?; I would if I could, but I just can't; easy for you to say, hard for me to do; I hear you, but that's just not possible; I don't know what to tell you; yeah, sure. But~; [phrase], he says...; phrasing it like that isn’t going to suddenly make it happen!; easier said than done; does it look like I'm not trying?; be that as it may, I just can’t; that ain't it, mate; no- the truth/reality is that; you say that, but...; now if i were to say it

tl.defexp: Keyboard smash
"It depends a lot on the context (could be jokey, or it could be a reaction to a punch or whatever) but generally "Oof!" has you covered."
"As in: 'something expected or predictable (e.g. running gag), typical or cliched development (in a story), something considered obligatory or guaranteed (in a certain situation)'"
tl.jpsam: 歌舞伎の約束では黒という色は見えないことになっている
tl.ensam: It is a convention of Kabuki that the color black is invisible.

tl.def: we're well past the point of~; little late to be worrying about~; the time for talk of ~ has long since passed; you wanna talk ~ NOW?; ~ he says. In the 11th hour, no less

tl.defexp: "適当 is often used to mean something more along the lines of 'mediocre' or 'inconsequential' rather than 'suitable' or 'appropriate'. You could compare it to the non-descriptive qualifiers 'rather' and 'somewhat' in English"
tl.jpsam: 適当にしろ; 適当な答え; 適当な立場
tl.ensam: Don't be a tryhard; Half-baked answer; Suitable position

tl.def: I said stop; cut me some slack here; have mercy, man; oh, come on!
that was close; you saved my bacon; I owe you one; thank God; I'm alive!

tl.defexp: Came across it in a narrative about a car with smoked windows, making it hard to see inside.
Works when "simulation" just feels too out there when a character visualizes a scenario.

tl.def: what the--?!; the hell!; oh shit; damn it all; oops; welp; oh God!
excited; enthusiastic; passionate; too focused; urgent; dire

tl.defexp: When talking about deep, as in profound, the "depth" can be seen as something that's hard to fully understand
Conveyed somewhere along the lines of "don't forget to like and subscribe to my channel!"

tl.def: unthinkable; preposterous; impossible; you're shitting me!; you gotta be lying; say it ain't so; holy shit

term: そんなこと聞いていない
romakana: そんなこときいていない
lit: I haven't heard of such a thing

tl.def: this is all news to me; first I've heard of it

lit: to turn an enemy into an ally

tl.defexp: Turning one's weakness into a strength in a particular situation.

tl.def: don't let your guard down; keep your guard up; stay frosty; stay vigilant; keep alert; no slacking; look alive

tl.defexp: More effective when actual size isn't being described

tl.def: well, (We) knew this would happen; saw that coming a mile away
keep your chin up; stay positive; be optimistic; it's not the end of the world

tl.defexp: Sexual lubricant

tl.def: you got it; sure thing; I hear ya
you're/they're here; glad to see you're here; look who showed up
good head on their shoulders; knows what's up; smart (as in clever)
exactly; absolutely; got it in one; you got that right; bingo

tl.defexp: Just in case you find yourself in a situation where the "white people" aren't caucasian or anything related to race, but actually people who are white.

tl.def: hello, anyone there?; we're letting ourselves in; excuse us; sorry for barging in (like this); thank you for welcoming us / the hospitality; coming through
tl.defexp: The important thing to note is that you're taking up someone else's time or attention, so what's being expressed here is a sense of humility and gratitude, though sometimes--as is the case for set phrases--it can be meant sarcastically.

tl.def: you're such an eyesore; you're getting in the way / on my nerves; you're distracting; I can't focus; shut up
I must go; see you; good bye; if you'll excuse me...; toodles; laters; be seeing you
tl.defexp: When said in parting, it can be synonymous with 失礼します.
"You..." is fine but it lacks punch sometimes especially when a character shows up and all they can say is that.

tl.def: let's get moving; time to go; let's split/skedaddle; gotta go; moving out; let us be off; I'm ready; let us proceed; onward we go; let's press on; onwards and upwards; gotta hustle
tl.defexp: It can mean the act of going somewhere or proceeding to do something

tl.def: ready when you are; I was born ready; I'll be waiting; just say the word; standing by
what's taking so long?!; come on!; hurry up!; faster!; what a slowpoke!; move those legs!; I don't have all day!
tl.defexp: When used by itself in dialogue, it's usually to tell someone to hurry up.

tl.def: take this!; eat this!; hiyah!; my chance!; gotcha!; you're open!; strike!
tl.defexp: Stock phrase often used as a battlecry so go crazy with it.

tl.def: now's my chance; me, me!; I'll handle this; time to show what I got / take the spotlight / be a hero; It's Me time; I've been waiting; finally...; alright; I shall go; let's go; I'm up; I'm going; very well; I got this; movin' out; now then...; yes?; here I go
tl.defexp:
Stock phrase often used in turn-based games to indicate the start of a character's turn so you'll very quickly run out of words (which is not always a bad thing) unless you vary it.
If anything, adjust to the character voice and refer to similar phrases like まかせて since it's their time to shine.

"This word sees use in all kinds of contexts, so you should carefully consider how you translate it. Just for example, I saw アイドル時代 recently, and this did not refer to 'an age of idols' (aka current year) but rather a character's *idol phase*"

This is somewhat complicated depending on where you're coming from, since "live" has carved its own place in anisong/seiyuu fandom so it works there. Outside it, though, it's gonna sound weird so know your audience before translating it as such.

"'Idol' has been sort of reimported into English, but personally I'd only translate it as "idol" if I didn't have context or was told to translate it that way. Generally, 'pop star' is a more accurate translation."

tl.def: a machine; a car or motorcycle, particularly one used for racing
tl.defexp: I've seen this erroneously translated as "machine gun" or just "machine" on multiple occasions in a context where a motorcycle or car is present or should be inferred.
tl.jpsam: マシンも良い調子だし、結局はそれが一番重要だ。
tl.ensam: We have a good car as well and at the end of the day that is the most important.

tl.def: handbook (ex. disability, school), badge (ex. cop's badge), ID
tl.defexp: Techou can really refer to any sort of small personal book that is either used for writing or identification. But it has to fall under that definition. I don't ever wanna see an American translate it as pocketbook again, because that means purse in American English. Techou is NOT a purse.
Newer slang. Used when looking down on someone.

tl.def: I kinda want X; I can do X, I guess
tl.defexp: Used when you don't want to do something, or want something you shouldn't, but don't want to come off as rude or pushy or admit your true intentions.
tl.jpsam: そろそろ返事欲しいんですけどー。
tl.ensam: I kinda wanted a response [to my confession] by now.

tl.defexp: Online slang. Supposed to mimic a creepy or pervy laugh, but used mockingly.
tl.jpsam: それはちょっと勇気いるけど、むしろありがたいっていうか…ドゥフ。
tl.ensam: It takes courage to do something like that, but I'd have to thank you... Nyehehe.

lit: yeah, I guess so; yeah I suppose; yeah, you're right

tl.def: yeah, I guess so; yeah, I suppose; yeah, you're right; せやな; そやね
tl.defexp: A Kansai saying that suggests agreement with a prior thought or suggestion. Can also be expressed as せやな or そやね.
A way of saying "thank you" in Kansai; informal.

term: 鬼が出るか蛇が出るか
romakana: おにがでるかへびがでるか
lit: there might be ogres or snakes

tl.def: there's no telling what might happen
tl.defexp: I've seen this translated literally in several works that I've edited (which might be understandable in a fantasy story at least), but it's a set expression. It's understood that actual ogres and/or snakes are almost never involved.
tl.jpsam: 鬼が出るか蛇が出るか全く判らん。
tl.ensam: God only knows what's out there.

tl.def: no big deal; whatever; who cares; meh; nah
tl.defexp: On its own, an all purpose dismissive interjection

tl.def: up first; the first person to try

tl.defexp:
Taken from the baseball term (Leadoff hitter in English) for the first player in the batting order. For concerts, this refers to the first one to perform in a series of acts at an event. This can be used regardless of whether they’re the first act of the day, or the first act of the second-half post intermission.
It's considered to be an important role since they serve to warm up the crowd. This term is very flexible has found use everywhere. Essentially, if you’re the first one in a group to do something, you’re the top batter.
In concerts, they're the closing act of the day. For multi-day events, the final act may be called ootori 大トリ instead.

tl.def: you can do it; go for it; don't give up; do your best
tl.jpsam: ファイトだよ！
tl.ensam: You can do it!

tl.defexp: "one of my fav things about japanese is using 1ミリ (ichimiri, 1mm) to mean "a bit" even when its not about physical distance"
tl.jpsam: この曲はエモいから聴いてって言われたけど1ミリも感じなかった
tl.ensam: I was told to listen to this song bc its super emotional but I didnt feel it for even 1mm.

tl.defexp: "I actually translated イタカー as cringemobile in Hello Lady."

romakana: ~しぼりきれないじゃないの？

tl.def: do you have the slightest idea how little that narrows it down?
to change your attitude back and forth so quickly, your hand turns into a drill
to change your attitude quickly, as in a flip-flop
